June 28, 2023
Tyrene Green
Osceola Youth Center
3030 Long Lane Rd
Evart, MI 49639
Re: License #: CI670414130
Dear Mr. Green:
Attached is the Original Licensing Study Report for the above referenced facility. The
study has determined substantial compliance with applicable licensing statutes and
administrative rules. Therefore, an original license is issued.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Osceola Youth Center is a 16-bed facility that is located in Evart, MI. Osceola
Youth Center is consists of two separate programs, an open shelter program and
a secure detention program within one building. Upon entry to Osceola Youth
2

Center there is a reception area to the left of the doorway with a seating area and
a receptionist desk/control area. The rooms off the reception area include a large
nurses office where medications will be securely stored, a large conference room,
and a guest bathroom. There are two additional doorways off the reception area,
one to the left of the entrance that leads into the detention multi-purpose room,
and the other door to the right of the entrance that leads into a large classroom
that will be used by the detention youth. Once in the classroom there is a door at
the back of the room that leads into another classroom that will also be used by
the detention youth. There is a door on the side of the classroom that goes into a
long hallway that is divided by two secure doors. The hallway between the
classroom and the first secure door has two offices on the left, an office, storage
area, and laundry room on the right. Once you pass through the secure doorway
there are two doors on the left side, one that goes into the detention youth’s multi-
purpose room which is a large room that has basketball hoops, set up for
volleyball nets, and room for tables for eating, and the other door goes into the
detention youth’s day room which is a large open room with television and seating
area. In the same hallway on the right side is eight bedrooms and one bathroom.
Each bedroom has a secured bed and a plastic shelf that is fixed to the wall. At
the end of this hallway is the second secure door which leads into the open
shelter program area. The shelter program area is set up in a rectangular shape
with three bedrooms and a bathroom along the right side, the far wall is made up
of five bedrooms along the wall, and on the left side is a large office. In the middle
area of the shelter area is the day room area which includes seating area and a
large table. The open shelter program has a doorway next to the office area that
will be used for entering/exiting the program to ensure sight/sound separation
from the detention youth.
The facility has serval other building on the campus, however only one of these
buildings will be used for the current program. This building is located next to the
building the youth will reside in and has the main kitchen that will prepare all the
youth’s food, a multi-purpose room that the shelter youth will use for eating and
recreation, and several offices for administrative staff. This building did not require
or have a fire or environmental inspection and therefore would only be used for
times with the youth are awake.
An Environmental Health Inspection occurred on May 31, 2023, and resulted in an
“A” rating, as did the Fire Safety Inspection conducted on May 24, 2023. The
facility has cameras in the common areas of the building. The facility is in an area
that does not zone or approve occupancy.
B. Program Description
Osceola Youth Center will be providing two programs for youth, an 8-bed open
shelter program for females ages 10-17, and an 8-bed secure detention program
for males ages 10-17. Staff for both programs will be trained in Safe Crisis
Management for de-escalation and restraint. Youth in both programs will remain in
their home school if able, or all services will be provided by the Mecosta-Osceola
3

School District. Medical, dental and vision issues which are both routine and
emergent in nature are coordinated through community health providers who are
responsible for the provision of health care services and health care oversight.
Osceola Youth Center Detention provides residential detention care to youth who
have detention care and behavioral support needs that require temporary care in
a secure, structured, supportive and trauma informed setting. The detention
program provides staff care twenty-four hours a day which consists of detention
care planning, crisis intervention, education, and health care services designed to
meet the individual youth’s needs. The program is highly structured, predictable,
and trauma informed that fosters personal growth, social development, and
responsibility through an array of comprehensive daily services. Staff led group
interventions are utilized to motivate and teach while providing interventions that
help youth achieve emotional and behavioral stability. Services and training
provided throughout placement include behavior motivation, human growth and
development, restoration, life skills, detention care, academic instruction, physical
fitness, and nutritional health. Upon admission and initial assessment, youth are
assigned a detention care track that focuses on educational and social needs.
Service delivery includes mindfulness strategies to help enhance the youth’s
capacity for emotional and behavioral control. Ancillary life skills and social skills
groups are available. The program utilizes a behavior motivation system centered
on positive reinforcement that promotes respect, healing, and positive behavior,
using a child-centered, strength-based, trauma-informed approach that fosters the
opportunity for healthy growth and development. The program recognizes that
youth served have suffered some degree of trauma and, as a result, there are
adverse effects on youth’s abilities to cope with everyday life circumstances. The
overarching goal of our model is to provide support, guidance, and interventions
to develop youth’s capacity to self-regulate and ability to internalize and improve
their behavioral and emotional functioning to prepare them for a healthy, safe, and
goal-directed future. All staff are educated and trained in Motivational Interviewing
and enhancement techniques to support youth through their process of personal
change and self-improvement. The program’s average length of stay is
approximately 14 days.
Osceola Youth Center Shelter Care provides residential shelter care programming
for youth who have mental health and behavioral needs that require temporary
care in a structured, supportive, and trauma-informed settings. The program
provides twenty-four-hour staff care for youth that consists of shelter care
planning, individualized shelter care counseling services, crisis intervention,
education, and health care services designed to meet the unique and
individualized needs of the youth. The program is a highly structured, predictable,
and accepting trauma-informed community that fosters personal growth, social
development, and responsibility through an array of comprehensive daily services.
Group and individual counseling interventions are utilized to motivate and teach
while providing interventions that help youth achieve emotional and behavioral
stability. Services and training provided throughout placement include behavior
4

motivation, human growth and development, restoration, life skills, shelter care,
academic instruction, physical fitness, and nutritional health. The focus
accentuates healing and working to make sure that youth have stable and
productive environments to which they can thrive. It means supporting workers,
and family healing while the youth is in the program and coordinating services to
support the progress made towards a long-term placement. Upon admission and
initial assessment, youth are assigned a shelter care track that focuses on
educational and social needs. Credentialed therapists are employed to deliver a
shelter care level of service for individual supportive counseling needs and crisis
management. Service delivery includes mindfulness strategies to help enhance
the youth’s capacity for emotional and behavioral control. Osceola Youth Center
Shelter Care will provide (at a minimum) weekly individual counseling services for
each youth. Individual counseling must be provided in accordance with the youth’s
shelter care needs as identified in the Individual Service Plan. Parents, family
members and pertinent supportive adults are encouraged to engage with the
youth through phone, in person, and service planning interactions throughout their
stay. Skill streaming for social and life skills development, independent living
skills, and mindfulness training are part of the weekly schedule. The program’s
average length of stay is approximately 30 days.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The agency was found in compliance.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
original license be issued.
